top_comment.text:
Um ok I'm South American and the only thing that was from South America was 
the Quinoa..   we dont eat beans like that  specially for brunch/ breakfast﻿
top_comment.author: ALEX Galarza

comments.text:
I'm from Chile and we don't usually eat those things but there are some 
places in Latin America like Cuba where they eat lots of beans (I have 
family there and they always eat beans) and my friends from Colombia always 
have beans with rice
comments.author: Ignacia Chacon

comments.text:
It is not meant to be something they eat but it is meant to remind you of 
the country when you eat it, and this will spicy and fluffy.
comments.author: mrdrebin123

comments.text: every south american eats beans!! que viva las caraotas
comments.author: Man Zoo

comments.text: Here in Chile we don't even eat quinoa because is expensive as hell.

comments.text: Mexicans and colombians do. I think he did a comb of everything!

comments.text: So you don't eat eggs?

comments.text: 挖~~~那個煎蛋.....垂涎啊!!!!! (翻滾)

top_comment.text:
Jamie's fresh and tasty brunch recipe uses a great South American staple 
food -- Quinoa. It's got loads of health benefits and if you've never tried 
it before give it a go for something a little bit different!  ‪#‎FoodTube‬﻿
top_comment.author: Jamie Oliver

comments.text: I'm starving now

comments.text:

Monday was the best lamb I've had (however did make a red wine gravey from 
the Juices for my mum) but was lush like

comments.author: Emily Higson

comments.text: quinoa is pretty yummy
comments.author: Jessica Schnell

comments.text: I love it
comments.author: Vanessa Morales

top_comment.text:
Oh dear... where do I start? this is definitely NOT a real South American 
brunch. I do not want to offend anyone here. I mean, black beans fried on 
olive oil? here in my country, we do eat black beans, but not that way, it 
is a sin to ruin them like that! And what's with the chili salad?? 
Coriander and spring onions are alright, but seriously. a little more 
research wouldn't hurt...﻿
top_comment.author: Misel 00

comments.text:
It's called "fusion"  cooking, like Cuban Chinese food.  Griffenb got it 
right.
comments.author: David Harlem

comments.text:
It's meant to be a tasty recipe, not a school report on a country's 
principal diet.  Of course it's not authentic South American food, he's not 
even on the same continent.
comments.author: griffenb

comments.text:
South America is massive, can you really say it doesn't at least mildly 
resemble a brunch people eat somewhere in South America?
comments.author: Chunkleberry Finn

comments.text:
He included mexican notes. Hence the beans and chili. I think it was more 
Latin american as a whole than south america.
comments.author: Patricia Ortigoza

comments.text:
He included mexican notes. Hence the beans and chili. I think it was more 
Latin american as a whole than south america.
comments.author: Patricia Ortigoza

top_comment.text:
Hey Jamie!

You don't rinse the quinoa? I've heard you have to to avoid bitterness... 
Disagree?﻿
top_comment.author: Nica Motles

comments.text:
I always do rinse it, i had my experience with bitter quinoa and i had to 
throw it away cuz it was bad! So always rinse to be sure?
comments.author: Patricia Ortigoza

comments.text:
I always do rinse it, i had my experience with bitter quinoa and i had to 
throw it away cuz it was bad! So always rinse to be sure?
